CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, February 1, 1958, pg. 1, reads: "Puzzled Spectator - While members of opposite races glide around the floor of Lexington Roller Skating Rink, Jan. 28, side by side in complete harmony, a puzzled spectator (center, wearing checkered shirt) looks on sternly, as if to scorn the new policy which no longer bars Negroes. The skating party was arranged and supervised by officials of the local branch of the NAACP.  It was the NAACP which charged former owners of the rink with racial discrimination, and resulted in a court ruling last year ordering the policy discontinued. - Harris Photo."Cutline for related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, February 1, 1958, pg. 1, reads: "No Incident - A group of the 20-member skating party rests along the railing of Lexington Roller Skating Rink as other members 'do their number.'  The skating party was staged without incident on Jan. 28, under the new policy which no longer bars Negroes.  It was supervised by Mrs. Marion Jordon, executive secretary, and Edward Shelton, staff assistant of the local branch of the NAACP. - Harris Photo."
TitMainTitle: Group of men, women, and teenagers roller skating, including young woman in center wearing dark plaid skirt and light colored sweater, in Lexington Roller Skating Rink
